segments.text: After the Curran faction called off the spring strike in 36, what did you and Curran do in the time before the fall strike was called?
We kept making plans and making contacts with the seamen aboard the ship, getting them to join the organization.
This still meaning the old ISU?
No, this meant the new group, really.
Well, we were trying to get, yes, we were trying to get these people active in the old ISU.
I forget, I don't remember how long this went on, but at one point we had to break it off because
while the rank-and-file took over the activities of the Union, the AFL did not recognize the rank-and-file groups.
For example, there was a group controlling each one of these, the decks, stewards, and engine departments.
a rank and file group controlling the actual meetings, but the old officials still control the money and the office.
Why do you think at this time, particularly after the spring strike, that the upper echelons of the ISU didn't change their tune?
Could they not recognize what was happening, or did they not care?
Carlson, Grains, Charlsburg, this group?
It's my own opinion and I can't prove this again that they were too close to the Steamship Company officials.
During this time between the strikes did they ever come to you and ask for your help?
No.
No?
No.
I became an outcast really as far as they were concerned.
Once the
Really, I became an outcast when we had that strike aboard the U.S. line ships, the radio operators.
I would have nothing more to do with them then.
Were you at the famous Union-Cooper meeting?
I was, indeed.
Could you explain that, or describe that, please?
Could you describe the meeting?
Or the preparation that went into it?
No, I can't.
I don't remember the details of it.
You don't remember if, well, when Turen made his entrance around 10 o'clock at night, had he been already tutored by someone to use the tactics that he did?
Or was this a spontaneous outburst by the dissident members who were outside the Union?
Well, Joe and I came into that meeting together, but I don't remember any of the details of it.
I really don't.
I just don't remember them.
I can see the old building.
I don't remember even how we came into that meeting now.
When was it, or do you know,
an approximate time when Curran and his group and your South decided that it was time to found a new union, that they actually gave up on the old ISU?
I would say just before the 37th strike.
It was perfectly clear.

I don't remember the details of what went on now, but that group went to the AFL-CIO in Washington to visit with the Green about the conditions that existed in the three branches and the officials and how they were disregarding the wishes of the members.
And the AFL, of course, said, no soap.
They're the officials, and they put another man in charge.
And I can't remember his name.
You mentioned Hunter.
That's not his name.
Anyway, the AFL put another person in charge of the seafaring unions, not one of the old elected officials.
And that person took the position of the old officials against the rank and file.
I want to say Hunter.
I think Hunter may have been his name, but I'm just not sure of that.
But that'll show up somewhere in some of the stuff that you get into.
Did you have anything to do with the curing groups
activities as far as the Copeland Continuous Discharge book goes?
I went with the group to Washington.
Who organized this?
Was this Kern or was this Patty Wayland?
Who was the spearhead for this march on Washington?
Joe Kern.
Joe Kern was?
Joe Kern was the spearhead for everything that took place.
He was the leader.
And as far as I was concerned, the important thing was to build him up, to make him the leader, because you can't take over a movement without a leader.
And he was the natural person to do this.
Did the Communists also recognize this?
Oh yes, yes.
They recognized this immediately.
So in your opinion then during this time period there were two factions who were vying for Curran's ear?
The basic rank and file and of course the Communists were trying to influence everything he did and they did influence him a lot.
There's no question about that.
They influenced me a lot.
Fortunately, we both had enough understanding to realize that we didn't want communism.
That was not what we were working for in these United States, and the thing we were working for with the seamen was literally to improve their conditions.
We were not working to build a
a communist government in the United States or a communist party in the United States.
We were working to help seamen.
And as far as I was concerned, the unlicensed seamen needed help just as bad as the radio operators did.
And if the radio operators were ever going to get anywhere, you had to have all of the people on the ship organized.

At this time when the rank and file was considering a national convention and before the National Maritime Union was named as such, did you and Curran and other groups ever approach John L. Lewis and his Committee for Industrial Organization before he actually founded the CIA?
No, not until after it was formed.
Do you have any idea where or from whom the name National Maritime Union came from?
I don't remember.
No, I really don't.
I just don't remember.
I don't remember whether we came up with that name before the convention or during the convention.
I really don't remember.
My main job during the convention was working on the Constitution, and I just don't remember the genesis of the National Maritime Union.
Ed, you were on the Constitutional Committee.
Yes.
How influential was William Merrill's standard on this?
What?
How influential?
in the writing of the Constitution was standard?
I would say not very much.
Not very much.
Who actually put together most of the Constitution?
Who was responsible for it?
Myself and a communist.
I can't think of his name.
I can see him.
Huh?
Doyle?
What?
Doyle?
No.
No?
No.
He was a little slight man.
He worked for the NMU after that as a researcher.
I know him.
I can see the man, but I can't think of his name.
But he and I did most of the work on the Constitution.
He was a communist at the time, and I knew he was a communist at the time.
What was a, what was,
What was the purpose of writing the 37th Constitution in such a way that it had so many democratic, or why was it such a democratic document?
Was this purposely written into the amendments?
Well, I guess it's because we got out the AFL-CIO, the AFL Constitution and the Declaration of Independence.
And that's what we wrote the Constitution by.
Were any of these amendments of it that were proposed written up specifically as a counterforce to the old ISU Constitution and the abuses that had been rendered under it?
Our primary purpose in writing the Constitution was to give the membership control of the union.
That was our primary objective in writing that Constitution.
That was Joe's and my primary thing.
Joe said that he wanted to come out of this with a constitution where the membership controlled the union.
How much input did Curran have in the constitution before it was presented to the convention?
Everything that we wrote, we checked with Joe.
Everything.
Who else looked at it beforehand, also for tacit approval?
Bill Standard looked at it.
He had very little to do with the original drafting.
The final drafting, he had a lot to do with.
Standard wasn't even in our meetings.
Myself and this one guy, and I can't think of his name to save my life, and I've known him for all this time.
I think he may be dead now, but I know he's not active in NMU.
Tommy, first name was Tommy, I'll think of it.
Not Ray?
Tommy Ray.
Tommy Ray?
That's the man, Tommy Ray.
He and I had most of the input into that Constitution.
Why did you?
And our sole purpose
Joe and I had discussed this many times, and we had discussed it with the communists.
This Roy Hudson, his name was.
We discussed it with him.
How about Al Lannan?
Did he have much input at this time?
None.
None?
None.
Al Lannan came along much later.
Much later.
Tommy Ray, though, did have input into it.
Whether Hudson had input into it through Ray, I don't know.
I suspect he did, but I don't know.
But in any event, Joe and I, in our discussion, we did not discuss any specific thing in the Constitution.
We discussed only the principle.
We wanted full and complete and final say and control of the membership.
That's number one.
So I dug out the AFL Constitution.
I took our Constitution, of course, the ARTA, and the Declaration of Independence.
Were the three major documents you used to put together?
That was the three major documents, and that was what we worked for.
And I remember that we did not want to use a very radical clause in the preamble of the AFL Constitution.
There was a very radical clause in there.
I can't remember now what it was.
But anyway, we thought that was a little too communist.
And it wasn't a communist document at all, of course.

As far as the Constitution goes in the first part, why did you include, and this is what makes the document so famous, why did you include as a part of the membership no discrimination as to race, creed, and color?
Was this felt to be important at the time?
Yes, we felt it was important because we felt that as long as any one person wasn't free as a merchant seaman, as free as the others, no discrimination against them, no one was.
It's a very basic fact that freedom flows
from freedom of everyone.
As long as you're not free to do something that I'm free to do, I'm not free to do that thing somewhere down the line.
Why did the Union, almost from its inception, have such a liberal policy toward blacks?
Wasn't this sort of a risky situation for the Union to take on at this time?
Yes, it was.
But again, black workers are competing against white workers for jobs.
And these jobs, we felt that these jobs should be free for everyone.
Was this prevalent in the industry at this time?
No.
I mean, the idea of black workers competing against white workers.
No, it was very segregated.
The only black workers in the industry were in the stewards department.
They were segregated into that department.
And...
So then this clause wasn't put in the Constitution to, as a type of lip service.
It was sincerely... No, it was put in there because we felt very strongly that you could not build a union which was controlled by the membership as long as
you permitted discrimination against any person.
Was there any one person who was insistent on the race clause being included there in the membership requirements?
More or less, was there anyone who really pressed this issue strongly?
The communist faction or the rank-and-file faction or an individual?
Well, I would say that Joe and I pressed the faction, but the communists also pressed it.
So there was no argument over that?
It was just agreement?
No, there was never any argument over that issue when the organization was set up.
There became some arguments over it later on.
But fortunately, I've been fortunate enough to locate some material by an economist called
Van Mises, Von Mises, did you ever hear of him?
Ludwig Von Mises.
He's from the Austrian School of Economics.
I would say after Adam Smith, he was probably the greatest economist that ever existed.
And one thing that he did in his work, particularly
that dealing with human action was to emphasize how you maintain freedom.
He dwelt on this considerably.
Fortunately, I was able to have been subjected to some of his writings.
He takes the whole thing of freedom back to free enterprise, where it really begins.
Unless businesses are free, workers can't be free.
Unless workers are free, business can't be free.
And he tied these two together in such simple terms and simple examples that even I could understand them.
And he influenced you then?
He definitely did influence me.
And he was, of course, a strong anti-communist.
And he also wrote some material on why socialism can't exist, why business has to be free.
And of course, he dealt with the fact that businesses are too stupid to really
maintain their freedom because they take every opportunity they can to reach into the government tills and avoid being free instead of really working for free enterprise like they should.
But that definitely influenced me.
I don't know.
Joe had no background on this except, I guess, hard experience, and he just said, right from the very first, he said, I don't see colors.
If the fellow happens to be sitting across from me and happens to be black or yellow, I don't see his color, I see the man.
And that was always his position.
And one thing that a Negro had better understand about Joe Curran in the union is that you don't come in talking to him about discrimination going on in the union from his office.
If a man came in with a legitimate complaint about an agent or anyone else discriminating against him, he got full hearing, of course, and showed me where he did it.
But I was in Joe's office once when a Negro came in and started ranting and inferred that Joe was discriminating.
Joe just got up out of his chair and went over and got him by the collar and by the seat of the pants and moved him out the door, said, don't ever come back.
Joe literally did not see colors.
It just was not in him to discriminate against anybody.
After the convention and the Constitution, who did you go to for national affiliation?
Did you go to Green first in the AFL or directly to Lewis and the CIO?
The organization never went back to Green, as I remember.
And they were never courted by Green?
Never what?
Courted?
No.
I don't think so.
If they were, I don't remember it.
After the convention and the Constitution, how is your relationship with the Union?
Are you still a president of the ARTA, or have you dropped this affiliation in ?
I dropped the affiliation of the ARTA when I didn't run again for president.
But how do you mean?
Am I a member of the ARTA or the NMU or what?
Right.
I'm a member of both of them.
member of both of the unions.
I'm an honorary lab member of both of them.
But I never joined the NMU.
This was a convention action that made me honorary lab member.
But your activities then would be specifically with the NMU after the convention and the Constitution, as far as your employment and?
No, I was never employed by the NMU.
Or you would be strictly in an advisory?
When I left the ARTA, I took a six months leave.
In other words, I just didn't do anything.
It was my intention not to do anything for six months.
At the end of the first month, I couldn't sit still.
I had to find a job.
So my wife said, well, why don't you just take another month before you start looking?
So I said, well, I can't stand it.
But anyway, I went for three months before I started looking.
And the first man I went to gave me a job.
So I went to Standard Oil of New Jersey, a fellow by the name of Hague.
And the reason I went to him was,
Because of my knowledge of him as being president of the ARTA, I saw how he worked amongst the ship owners.
And he was the leader of that group.
And almost anything he said went.
What time would this be?
Oh, this was 19, it would be 19,
from about 1937.
I think I left in 1937.
I don't remember now the date.
Well, anyway, while I was still president of the ARTA, I went to meetings of ship owners, you know, between ship owners and the unions.
And he was the basic leader of the group.
So I went to him and told him that I was looking for a job.
He had one that I wanted.
He said, you've got it.
What is it?
I told him what I wanted to do was to head up their radio department.
He said, fine.
I never did one thing in the radio department, not one thing.
He said, well, the first thing I want you to do is to make a trip around the country to all of our offices and to all of our ships that happen to be in port.

I want you to look at the conditions that exist, talk with the people in these offices and see what they think of the conditions that exist on the ships, whether or not changes should be made and so forth.
Come back and report to me.
Then we will get down to your specific assignment."
I came back and reported to him, told him what I thought ought to be done.
He says, it'll be done.
I had men put on the ship to make surveys that I outlined as to what they should do.
This is after the NMU is founded?
Beg your pardon?
This is after the NMU is founded?
This was after the NMU was founded, yes.
What was your reaction in Standard Oils, and I guess the NMUs, to Lundberg's founding of the SIU in 1938?
Well, we knew that it was founded by the ship owners.
And of course, I learned specifically yes that it was when I got into Standard Oil.
The main supporter was Eastern Steamship Company then, and there was one other, Isthmian Line, U.S. Steel.
They were the ones who really paid for it.
They footed the bills.
Did Curran try to seek Lundberg's help out, or did he ever?
He did.
And what was the result of that?
My own analysis at the time was
that Lundberg was a very insecure person.
And he saw in Joe Curran the growth of a very dynamic leader.
And I think, I still think this was the problem.
What about Harry Bridges?
Harry Bridges was interested in two things.
Advancing the Communist Party and keeping Harry Bridges in charge.
So is it your opinion then that, or do you think that Curran was a Communist Party member?
Curran?
Excuse me, Bridges.
Yes, I know he was.
Well, I don't know it.
He said he was.
He told you then?
Oh, yes.
He made no bones of it amongst the people he knew.
What about, could we move on to the 1939 per se?
It seems to be a very important year as far as the National Maritime Union goes.
Specifically,
Do you have any thoughts or any recollections of the Mariners Club?
No, just generally basically what they tried to do.
You say the 1939, you're talking about the convention?
Well, and the tanker strike, the convention, the Mariners Club, the five points program.
At this time you were employed by Standard Oil?
1939, yes, I was with Standard Oil.
And so your affiliation, you weren't that close to Nicaran?
I was always very close to Curran.
And in an advisory capacity?
Or more as a friend?
More as a friend.
He would discuss with me problems when he wanted my advice.
Okay.
Tuning in then on the tanker strike of 39, first of all, why do you think it came about?
And what was Kieran's stand on the strike?
I think it came about because of stupidity of the Communist Party.
The Communists were in strong position in the NMU.
There were more Communist officials in the NMU than there were non-Communists.
And they forced the strike because of, I think, stupidity.
Again, Tommy Ray played, tried to play a very important part in that thing.
He tried to prevent that strike.
He told them.
Matter of fact, he told me just exactly what would happen.
I didn't think it would happen that way.
I was still with Standard Oil.
He said, the strike will take place, the people will pile off the ships, and the company will have the ships manned, and there'll be very few, if any, delays in it.
And the strike will be lost, and we'll lose our contract in this company.
And I said, well, I agree with you that you're going to lose the contract.
But I didn't think that you would get the seamen to pile off.
I thought they would stay aboard the Standard Oil or New Jersey ships.
Anyway, the rest of the Communist Party and Joe said that we just, I guess we just have to have the strike.
I don't see any way we can prevent it.
So he wasn't in favor of the strike?
He was not in favor of it because he'd already worked out an agreement with the company.
The agreement was that the
Instead of, the real fight was over the Union Hall, shipping through the Union Hall.
So he had worked out an agreement with Haig that the company would call the Union Hall and the seaman then would go directly to the company's office and from that company's office to the ship.
The Union didn't want that.
The communists didn't want that.
They wanted the man to go direct from the Union to the ship instead of the company.
Why do you think Standard Oil took that position?
What?
Why did Standard Oil take that position?
Because this was a procedure that they had always followed.
This was where their records for the seamen started out.
And when the seamen came ashore from the ship, that's where their records were kept.
And this was the way they operated.
Now, they could have moved that office over to Bayonne, where the ship was.
But if the ship goes somewhere else, the man would have to go to Bayonne.
They had determined that this was the most centralized part to handle it.
It wasn't uptown.
It was downtown, where it was handed to the seamen.
And Joe recognized this.
And that's why he agreed to this particular thing.
Once the 39th strike started, what was Standard Oil's position?
Did they want to break the strike then, or did they want to continue relations?
No, no.
They said that we offered the Union what we considered to be a fair situation.
Joe considered it to be a fair situation.
You approved of it as being a fair situation to me.
And we won't accept less.
If that means tying up our ships for months, we'll tie them up for months.
It's that simple.
Once the strike started, that was it.
They would have no more use for a national union?
No.
The Union will not back up its leader.
We can't back up its leader, and we're not going to buy the leader.
Do you think at any time Standard Oil would have wanted to force the strike?
No, not at that time.
They would have been happy with the contract.
They were happy with it.
Yes.
I would say that there were some people in Standard Oil who were not happy with it, but Bob Haig was head of the Marine Department, and he was happy with it, and that's what counted.
Didn't Haig die during the strike?
No, he died in 1940.
I think it was 1940.
I may be wrong.
He may have died during that strike, but I don't believe he did.
Why do you think the Union lost the strike?
Because they called it.
They just didn't have the resources?
No, they didn't have the resources, didn't have the ability to fight Standard Oil.
They had no access to the plant where the ships dock.
Standard Oil had a ship with it, would bring strike breakers aboard and house them on that ship, feed them on that ship, ship, another ship come in and take them right off of it and put it on it.
I'd like to mention some names and

if you had any comments on them as our insights on them um ferdinand smith how important was he in the union ferdinand smith was an incompetent ass he was put in the position solely because he was a negro and the most prominent negro in the group by whom who placed him now who supported him joe supported him
Did Smith play any large part in the Union's desegregation stand?
No, he did not.
He was a figurehead?
He was a pure figurehead.
He had no ability or no nothing.
He was really an impediment to the Union's growth, his incompetence.
Could you give some examples of that, or what are you feeling?
Well, it was just general incompetence.
He really had no expertise in anything.
As Secretary of Treasury, he couldn't write a letter, he couldn't make a financial statement, he couldn't do anything.
Why did the party push him then?
Well, there was no one else to push.
And they felt they needed a black...
They felt they needed a black person.
What about Blackie Myers?
Black and Myers had a great personality, but that really is all he had, too, was personality.
He really had no competence handling business in the organization, but the seamen liked him.
He was well liked by the seamen.
Did he have much input with Joe?
Well, of course, he would talk to Joe about anything and everything that he wanted to.
But when it came down to really coming up with important decisions, he just wasn't there.
He didn't have that kind of ability.
He could, for example, if it was routine matters of settling beefs on a ship that a seaman had, he could do that.
And he normally did not do it by referring to the agreement.
He did it through his personality, pure and simple.
And he could get a seaman to do almost anything.
So he was a type of dynamic personality like Joe Kern as far as the rank and following.
Yes, he was.
He was a very personable, very personable person.
What about Jack Lawrenson?
Jack Lawrenson at that time was the best educated of the seafaring group in the leadership.
But he had some problems.
Drinking being one.
The other one wanting to work at night instead of in the daytime.
Another one chasing girls.
Not that I'm against any of these things, understand, but he put them ahead of work.
Don't let work interfere with my pleasure.
But as far as actual academic training, he was by far ahead of any of us.
How did Myers and Smith and Lawrenson, how did they get into the upper brackets of the leadership in the union?
Well, I think basically because of Communist Party support.
Figureheads, or were they the driving force?
Or was there someone behind pushing them up?
I don't know, really.
But I think the party is the one who got them to run.
This I don't know.
But I think knowing as much as I do about the party, I would assume.
that this is the way it happened, but I don't know that.
M. Headley Stone came from a Great Lakes ship, and he worked himself up through the
by being active on the lakes and then coming into headquarters.
I don't know how he was brought into headquarters.
I don't remember.
I should, but I don't.
I just don't remember.
But Headley was an able person.
He, when an idea was, he was good on raising ideas.
He was a thinking person.
He was an idea person, and he would come up with ideas, and he had good positions when he came up with them, and if you came up with ideas, he had good positions on them.
He was an able person, but he had family problems that ruined his career.
Excuse me, what about Neil Hanley?
Neil Hanley.
I would say that Neal was just a...
I don't really know how Neal Hanley ever got elected to anything, really.
Joe Stack?
Joe Stack was a party hack.
He had some personality traits that helped him, I think, but that's about all.
when he and Joe had the showdown.
It was one vote apart.
Have you had any input on that situation?
Just other than reading the minutes of the convention.
Well, at the convention, I don't remember what the issue was now.
Do you recall what the issue was from reading?
Procedurally, in the convention, I believe, it was the first time that Statt challenged his curing.
Well, anyway, whatever it was.
Wasn't there also a wage dispute or contract at the time?
I don't remember the issue.
I don't remember what it was.
But the party guys lined up against Joe.
And Joe went down the line of the guys who were leading from the floor, the party guys.
They were well planted on that floor.
And he referred to each one of them.
One of the guys tried to be an actor and failed.
And he said, part-time actor, so-and-so, this is his position.
Joe then went on around all of them.
And Joe stacked, this is his position.
My position is a very, very simple one.
I'm interested in the seamen and interested in the Union.
I'm not interested in the Communist Party as such.
I have never fought the Communist Party in this Union, as long as they fought for issues that would help the seamen.
I've understood all along that their only interest in building this Union is to build a power base for themselves.
I've never stood in their way to do that as long as they
worked for the betterment of the union.
But anyway, when it was all over, and I'll never understand this in my life, why the party let it happen.
The Honest Ballot Association counted the ballots, and there was one vote difference.
Curran won by one vote.
And not a one of those party guys asked for a recount.
Most stupid thing, Joe and I talked about that for a long time after he got away with it.
I was still with Standard Oil at the time, but I happened to be at the convention.
How long did you stay affiliated with Standard Oil?
I left there at the end of 1940.
No.
Maybe it was 1939.
It was 1939 I left.
left Standard Oil.
So, so Haig would have had to die in 39.
I went with the Actors Union in 1940, and I left there.
I was, I took, I signed a one-year contract with the Actors Union, and that was in 1940 sometime, and I left there in 1941 sometime.
Did you go back to NMU then?
No.
When I left there, I set up
